review:
I fucking love(d) this game. I've been a player since 2016. There is just no competetive shooter like it. It's crisp fun gameplay with lots of awesome characters. Colourful and really diverse. I could praise this game till death.

However the current state of this game and Blizzard is just awful. Don't get me wrong, this game is still a ton of fun. But it could be so much more than that. The community took one hit after another just because Blizzard was greedy for money. The devs don't really care about this game anymore, the monetization is horendous with even the scrapped pve recycled missions costing 15 euros. This game feels like pure greed right now, bringing back old features they scrapped in a worse way. The league is dying. And and and.... 

I just wish they would've never announced Overwatch 2 :(

ã€‚

cat

Once upon a time, I had a cat, I had ten dollars, I would buy it food for eight dollars, bathe it often, and it was very sticky to me.

Later, I took it out to play, passers-by thought it was cute, they fed it cat food, ham sausage, I was very unhappy because it was mine. I wanted to carry it home, but he broke away from me and meowed at the person who gave it good food, I hugged him a few times and he didn't go with me, and scratched me, so I turned around and left.....

Later, I came across it by chance on the road, and it was dirty. Passers-by will only give it good food and play with it, but they will not take it home and bathe it. It saw me and followed me home, I shut it out, it meowed outside the door, it was very uncomfortable,
but I wouldn't want it anymore
.

I've been an OW player since day one, 1000+ hours in the game, a lot of good faith, patience, coping, I've forgiven the devs a lot of bs and questionable shenanigans, but I can't stand the corporate greed that eviscerates the playerbase any longer. How great would it be if a game company would actually focus on making a game fun rather than making long empty promises and not deliver the final product in the end. Highly do no recommend this steaming of pile of garbage for human consumption.

Overwatch 2: A Disheartening Step Backwards

Overwatch 2 had the potential to redefine the trajectory of the beloved franchise and cater to its dedicated fanbase. However, upon diving into the game, one can't help but feel that this sequel not only fails to elevate the experience but rather diminishes it in several critical ways.

Pay-to-Win Dynamics: One of the most glaring issues is the game's apparent move towards a pay-to-win model. While it's understandable that a business needs to generate revenue, Blizzard seems to have forgotten a key principle: respect for the player. Forcing users to choose between shelling out money or investing a near-impossible 60 hours a month to acquire new characters feels like a slap in the face, especially for casual players who can't dedicate that amount of time.

Persistent Balance Issues: It's no secret that Overwatch faced its fair share of balance complaints. We hoped that with Overwatch 2, Blizzard would have taken the feedback to heart and made necessary adjustments. However, the balance issues persist, leading to repetitive metas, gameplay frustration, and the sidelining of some heroes entirely. What was the point of a sequel if not to address and refine these foundational elements?

DÃ©jÃ  Vu Gameplay: Drawing parallels between Overwatch 2 and its predecessor is inevitable, but the similarities are startling. Instead of feeling like a sequel, Overwatch 2 feels more like an "Overwatch 1.5." The maps, mechanics, and overall gameplay remain so unchanged that it's hard to justify the sequel's existence. Sequels should take risks, innovate, and expand upon the original's framework. Overwatch 2 feels too familiar and lacks innovation.

Broken Promises: Many players, including myself, were looking forward to the promised PvE mode with RPG elements â€“ a potential game-changer that could have set Overwatch 2 apart from the original. The absence of this feature is not only disappointing but downright misleading for fans who were waiting with bated breath. The game promised evolution and delivered regression.

In conclusion, Overwatch 2 feels like a missed opportunity. Instead of crafting a game that built upon the successes and lessons of the original, Blizzard appears to have played it safe â€“ and even taken a step back. While the graphics may be shinier and the roster expanded, at its core, Overwatch 2 fails to capture the magic and innovation that its predecessor brought to the table. One can only hope that future updates will address these glaring issues, but for now, Overwatch 2 stands as a lesson in how not to craft a sequel.

Who would have thought that overwatch 1, which won the game of the year award in 2016, would turn into overwatch 2.
